d:desc.d:p: This element encloses the entire corpus and is the common ancestor of all other elements.
XPath: /*

This element contains metadata about a TEI file. Where used in corpus.xml, it contains data referenced by @xml:id from across the rest of the corpus. It includes names and other details of scribes and abbreviations, for example.

When a direct child of teiHeader, fileDesc contains bibliographical information about the file itself. It is also used within msItem/biblFull to contain a keyword list relating to the individual text; this latter structure is mostly unnecessary for the purposes of the corpus but is required for TEI conformance.
This contains the most basic bibliographical information about the work to which it relates, namely, the title and optionally details of anyone responsible.

Where its parent is teiHeader/fileDesc, it provides details for the entire TEI file. When that file is corpus.xml, it contains the corpus title and a list of those who have worked on the corpus in various capacities. Where that file is a transcription file, it provides a title for the transcription and names the editor primarily responsible for that transcription, although it is likely that it has been reviewed by multiple team members in reality.
Where its parent is biblFull/fileDesc (i.e. it relates to an individual text), it provides the title for that text.
This is used in a variety of contexts to contain the title of a file, bibliographical work, or a transcribed text within the corpus or a subsection thereof.

Even where the title element appears within a transcription (e.g. TEI/text/body/div/head/title), it remains part of the editorial apparatus. In other words, the title element is never used to mark up titles that appear in manuscripts. For avoidance of doubt, the title element is also never used for a person's title.

d:list.d:item: @type is also only used in the context of a bibliography entry, where it distinguishes a condensed version of a work's title from the full version.

d:desc.d:p: The respStmt element contains other elements detailing one or more individuals' responsibility for a file or bibliographical work.
The name element is used in a variety of contexts to contain an anthroponym, toponym, demonym, or other sort of name.
Where it appears within respStmt, it contains the name of an individual responsible for a file or bibliographical work. In this context, the name is split into forename and surname.

Where it appears within a transcription (text//name), it is used to mark up the occurrence of a name in a transcription. In this context, it must contain at least one w element and could contain any of the markup used for transcribed text (e.g. unclear, space). If part or all of the name requires emendation, the choice element must be contained within name and not contain it. name can also contain a nested name element, where one name contains another name (e.g. Mael Coluim).
The following attributes are in active use with name:

d:list.d:item: @id: all name elements require this attribute to be compliant with the DASG schema.
@type: when the name element is used to mark up a name in a transcription, this identifies what sort of name it is (e.g. personal, place).

@corresp: when the name element is used to mark up a placename in a transcription, this attribute can be used to link to an entry for that name in an external placenames database (e.g. logainm.ie) via an URL. It can be used whether or not the word(s) in the name have also been linked to headwords and the same URL can be used here and for a contained word's @lemmaRef.

d:desc.d:p: Other attributes (@full, @instant) are at the time of writing (July 2021) assumed by the schema but are not actively used in the mark-up.
resp is used within respStmt to describe a responsibility belonging to the person named in the sibling name element.

When used in the fileDesc element relating to a TEI file, this element contains information relating to the publication of the file and its contents, such as who is responsbile for it and any restrictions on its use.

When used in the fileDesc element relating to a text item from a transcription (msItem/biblFull/fileDesc/publicationStmt), this element simply contains the statement that the item is a "Draft transcription"; publication is already provided by the publicationStmt at file level.
authority refers to the body responsible for the file and its publication.

In corpus.xml, this element contains the contact details for the Faclair na Gàidhlig project and is identified with the @xml:id "authority". Elsewhere, this element links to these details via @sameAs="authority".
This contains contact details for the Faclair na Gàidhlig project, comprised of a series addrLine elements.
This contains a line of the street address for the Faclair na Gàidhlig project.
This contains an email address for the Faclair na Gàidhlig project.
The meaning of this element varies depending on context.
When it appears within addrLine, it contains a telephone number for the Faclair na Gàidhlig project.

When it appears within a transcription, it is used to mark up a number that cannot be tagged as a single word and link to a dictionary headword or where the number appears in a manuscript as apparatus rather than in a syntactic context.
This contains information on how the file can be used. This is set to "restricted" via status and contains the following (within p): "For internal use by the Faclair na Gàidhlig/DASG projects."
The attribute @default is at the time of writing (July 2021) assumed by the schema but is not actively used in the mark-up.
p is a very widely used element. It is used to contain text belonging in a single paragraph.
In corpus.xml and in the teiHeader of transcription files and the hwData file, it is used to organise prose metadata added by editors.

Within transcriptions (text//p), it is used to contain transcribed prose. A new p element is begun when the text switches back from verse to prose, when the scribe visually indicates a major new subdivision of a prose text, or if the editors feel a new paragraph is needed for ease of reading.
The attribute @part is at the time of writing (July 2021) assumed by the schema but is not actively used in the mark-up.
When used in corpus.xml (/teiCorpus/teiHeader/fileDesc/sourceDesc), sourceDesc contains the project bibliography.

When used in a transcription file header (/TEI/teiHeader/fileDesc/sourceDesc), sourceDesc contains details on the texts transcribed from the manuscript in question (msContents) and a physical description of the manuscript (physDesc).
This element contains a bibliography. The type of works detailed in the bibliography is indicated via @type.
The attribute @default is at the time of writing (July 2021) assumed by the schema but is not actively used in the mark-up.

This element contains details about a particular manuscript. It can be used to list a manuscript within the corpus bibliography in corpus.xml or in the transcription file header to describe the manuscript from which transcription has been made.
The attribute @status is at the time of writing (July 2021) assumed by the schema but is not actively used in the mark-up.

This element contains identifying details about a manuscript. When used in the corpus bibliography in corpus.xml, the manuscript is assigned a unique ID via @xml:id. When used in transcription file headers, this ID is referenced via @sameAs.
Used within msIdentifier, this contains the location of the manuscript repository.
Used within msIdentifier, this contains the name of the manuscript repository.
Used within msIdentifier, this contains the manuscript's shelfmark.
How idno is being used is identified by @type.
This optional element within msIdentifier can be used to provide a name commonly in use for the manuscript being identified (e.g. 'The Yellow Book of Lecan' for Dublin, TCD H.2.16 (1318)).

This provides information on a manuscript's history. When used within the corpus bibliography, it simply contains the manuscript's approximate date (history/origin/date). When used within a transcription file header, it contains narrative metadata describing the manuscript's history (history/summary/p).
This is used within the corpus bibliography to provide the manuscript's approximate date (history/origin/date).

When used in corpus.xml or in a transcription file header, this element provides a date for a manuscript(history/origin/date), bibliographical work (listBibl/biblStruct/monogr/imprint/date), or scribe (profileDesc/handNotes/handNote). For bibliographical works, this is a calendar year. For manuscripts and scribes, it is a century or pair of centuries.

When used within a transcription, this element is used to mark up a date, but only when this date is in a format that cannot be analysed and marked up as words. For example, "1411" would be marked up with date, whereas "annaladh an tigerna ann so .i. mile bliadain cetra cead acus seacht bliadna acus tri .xx." ("the year of the Lord today, 1467") would be marked up as normal transcribed text.
In terms of the use of date to provide a date for a scribe, this can require particularly complex use of attributes:

d:list.d:item: @from and @to indicate a precise span of years in which the scribe is known to have been active, where this information is available. If there is only evidence for them being active in a single year, then both attributes point to that year.
@cert provides an editorial certainty level for the dating information contained in the rest of the element.

d:desc.d:p: At the time of writing (July 2021), the dating information for scribal hands is in some disrepair and could use thorough checking in terms of data and standardisation in terms of encoding.
Where date is used to provide the date of a manuscript, the century in which the manuscript was mainly created is indicated via @from-custom.
All date elements require an @id attribute to be compliant with the DASG schema.
